  sgcool_label_text: This carte de visite shows a  studio photograph of two children posing with a porcelain drum stool
 before a painted backdrop of a landscape with houses. This photograph was probably taken by Pun Lun photography studio at High Street in Singapore. \r\n\r\nPun Lun (1864 – c.1900) was a Chinese photographer
 with a successful studio in Hong Kong and branches in Foochow (Fuzhou)
 Saigon and Singapore.\r\n\r\nStudios were already established across the Strait Settlements and the Dutch East Indies by the 1840s and became increasingly prevalent in the 1850s. During the 1920s
 Chinese-owned studios dominated the studio photography trade in Southeast Asia.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This carte de visite shows a  studio photograph of two children posing with a porcelain drum stool, before a painted backdrop of a landscape with houses. This photograph was probably taken by Pun Lun photography studio at High Street in Singapore. 

Pun Lun (1864 – c.1900) was a Chinese photographer, with a successful studio in Hong Kong and branches in Foochow (Fuzhou), Saigon and Singapore.

Studios were already established across the Strait Settlements and the Dutch East Indies by the 1840s and became increasingly prevalent in the 1850s. During the 1920s, Chinese-owned studios dominated the studio photography trade in Southeast Asia.
